title: Practical Repair Resource: Equipment Fault Handling and Cost Control Advice
content:
I. Common Faults and Repairs for Home Appliances

1. Refrigerator Not Cooling / Poor Cooling Performance

• Common Causes: Poor power connection, incorrect thermostat settings, excessive dust on the condenser, refrigerant leakage

• User Self-Inspection Steps:

a. Ensure the plug is securely inserted and the socket has power (test with another appliance)

b. Check if the thermostat is set to a reasonable level (recommended 1-2 levels in summer, 3-4 levels in winter)

c. Clean dust from the condenser (located at the back or bottom of the refrigerator) using a soft brush or vacuum cleaner

d. Check if the door seal is airtight (place a piece of paper when closing the door; if the paper slides easily when pulled, the door seal needs replacement)

• Cases Requiring Professional Repair: If the refrigerator still doesn’t cool after self-inspection, it may be due to compressor failure or refrigerant leakage—contact a repair technician for inspection

2. Washing Machine Not Spinning / Excessive Noise

• Common Causes: Unbalanced laundry load, clogged drainage pipe, loose motor belt, aging shock absorbers

• User Self-Inspection Steps:

a. Pause the machine, rearrange the laundry, and ensure even distribution of clothes in the drum

b. Check if the drainage hose is kinked; remove the filter to clean hair and debris (the filter is usually located at the bottom or front of the machine)

c. If there is a sharp noise during spinning, check if the washing machine is placed stably (adjust the bottom feet to level the machine)

• Cases Requiring Professional Repair: If the machine still doesn’t spin after cleaning, or makes a "buzzing" sound of the motor idling, it may be due to a broken belt or motor failure

3. Air Conditioner Not Heating / Foul Odor from Air Outlet

• Common Causes: Incorrect mode setting, clogged filter, outdoor unit frosting (in winter), insufficient refrigerant

• User Self-Inspection Steps:

a. Confirm the air conditioner is in "Heating" mode and the temperature is set at least 5℃ higher than the indoor temperature

b. Remove the indoor unit filter, rinse it with clean water (add a small amount of neutral detergent if heavily soiled), and reinstall it after drying

c. When the outdoor temperature is below 0℃ in winter, the air conditioner may enter defrost mode—wait 10-15 minutes for heating to resume

• Cases Requiring Professional Repair: If there is still no hot air after cleaning the filter, or a pungent odor comes from the air outlet (possibly due to mold on the evaporator or aging wires)

II. Repair Guide for Electronic Devices

1. Cracked Phone Screen / Unresponsive Touch

• User Recommendations:

◦ If only the outer screen is cracked (display works normally and touch function is usable), temporarily protect it with a tempered glass screen protector to prevent further damage

◦ If the touch function is unresponsive, first restart the phone to rule out system faults; if the issue persists, check for liquid intrusion into the screen (power off immediately if detected)

• Repair Notes:

a. Choose a repair service that provides genuine parts to avoid display discoloration or touch delay caused by non-genuine screens

b. Back up phone data before repair to prevent data loss

c. Confirm the repair service provides a warranty of at least 30 days after repair

2. Laptop Blue Screen / Failure to Boot

• Common Causes: Corrupted system files, loose RAM module, hard drive failure, poor heat dissipation

• User Self-Inspection Steps:

a. Failure to boot: Check if the power adapter is powered on; try removing the battery (for removable models) and powering the laptop directly with the adapter

b. Blue screen: Press F8 (F12 for some models) to enter Safe Mode when restarting, then uninstall recently installed software or drivers; frequent blue screens may indicate hardware issues

c. Poor heat dissipation: Clean dust from keyboard gaps and air vents, and use a cooling pad to lower the laptop temperature

• Cases Requiring Professional Repair: If Safe Mode is inaccessible, or a "Hard Drive Error" message appears on boot, the hard drive or RAM module needs inspection

III. Tips for Choosing Repair Services

1. How to Select a Reliable Repair Agency

• Qualification Verification: Confirm the agency has industry-recognized service qualifications and check for clear repair processes and complaint handling mechanisms

• Reputation Assessment: Check user reviews on local service platforms, focusing on feedback such as "post-repair problem recurrence rate" and "quotation transparency"

• Quotation Confirmation: Request a detailed quotation before repair, specifying parts costs and labor fees to avoid "repair first, price increase later"

2. Post-Repair Notes

• Keep repair documents (invoices, warranty cards) with clear notes on the repaired parts and warranty period

• Use the device as advised by the repair technician (e.g., let a newly repaired refrigerator stand for 2 hours before powering on)

• If the same fault occurs again shortly after repair, request free re-repair in accordance with the warranty terms

IV. Suggestions for Controlling Repair Costs

1. Prioritize DIY Repairs for Minor Faults: Tasks such as replacing refrigerator door seals, cleaning washing machine filters, and changing air conditioner filters require no professional tools. Parts can be purchased through official platforms, costing only 1/5 to 1/3 of professional repair fees.

2. Compare Quotations from Multiple Providers: Consult 2-3 repair agencies for the same fault to avoid low-price traps (e.g., over-repair, use of inferior parts)

3. Pay Attention to Equipment Warranty Period: For devices under warranty, contact the brand’s official after-sales service first to avoid voiding the warranty due to self-repair

4. Regular Maintenance to Extend Equipment Life: Clean the refrigerator condenser every 3 months, the washing machine filter every month, and the air conditioner filter every 2 months—this can reduce more than 70% of common faults
